children: A 62-year-old asymptomatic woman is evaluated for an incidental finding of leukocytosis. Leukocyte count is 31,750/µL (31.75 × 10
/L) with 93% lymphocytes, 4% neutrophils, 2% monocytes, and 1% bands.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The key to diagnosis is the recognition of an increased blood leukocyte count resulting from increased numbers of mature lymphocytes and “smudge cells” on peripheral blood smear, as demonstrated in this image (

), which are characteristic of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Smudge cells are caused by mature-appearing peripheral lymphocytes that are abnormally fragile and that become damaged during slide preparation.
